countermeasure.name: Isolate Azure instances into different VNets
countermeasure.desc:
Specify a VNet for the Azure instance as a launch parameter. Applications that run on the Cloud instance can use the VNet security configuration when they access Azure resources. 

Remediation: 
You can configure an Azure cloud service from Solution Explorer in Visual Studio.

reference.name: MS Azure - Create a virtual network with multiple subnets

test.steps: Check that the Azure instances are into different VNets.

countermeasure.name: Isolate Azure resources into separate VNets by function
countermeasure.desc:
Place the resources into separate VNets according to their use (production, development, test). Placing such resources accordingly ensures that a resource of a higher security level is not exposed by the security settings of a lower labeled VNet.

Remediation: 
  1. Identify the resources that exist in an incorrect VNet.
  2. Migrate or move it to the correct Vnet.

reference.name: MS Azure - Azure Virtual Network

test.steps:
1. Identify the resources that exist in an incorrect VNet.
  2. Check that the resources are into the correct Vnet.

countermeasure.name: Recertify user access
countermeasure.desc:
Do regular reviews of accounts on the system and verify that it doesn't exist stoled or fake accounts. With this process is ensured that there are not compromised accounts by former employees or by attackers.

Remediation: 

At least every 90 days complete the following: 
  1. Log in to the Azure portal as an owner.
  2. Select Azure Active Directory.
  3. Go into "Users and groups" > "All users".
  4. For any user that should not exist:
  5. Select the user.
  6. Click "Delete".

reference.name: MS Azure - Assign a user or group to an enterprise app in Azure Active Directory

test.steps:
1. Log in to the Azure portal as an owner.
  2. Select Azure Active Directory.
  3. Go into "Users and groups" > "All users".
  4. Check that each user has got an assigned account.

countermeasure.name: Register a Security contact for your Azure account
countermeasure.desc:
Provide the security contact details for the Azure subscription. Microsoft Security Response Center (MSRC) performs security monitoring of the Azure network and infrastructure and receives threat intelligence and abuse complaints from third parties.

Microsoft will use this information provided to contact if the MSRC discovers that customer data has been accessed by an unlawful or unauthorized party. Also, this provides the means of ensuring these advisories are routed to the security team, especially if a distribution email address is used. 

Remediation: 
  1. Access "Azure Security Center". 
  2. In the "Recommendations" tab choose "Provide security contact details". 
  3. Once filled, save changes.

reference.name: MS Azure - Provide security contact details in Azure Security Center

test.steps:
1. Access "Azure Security Center". 
  2. In the "Recommendations" tab choose "Provide security contact details". 
  3. Check that all fields are filled.

threat.name: Attackers make undetected and unaudited changes to system configurations
threat.desc: If audit trails are not properly protected, an attacker could gain access to the system, modify the status of resources or exfiltrate sensitive data without being noticed.

threat.name: Attackers gain unauthorized access to the root account due to the lack of configuration of the account
threat.desc: Attackers could gain unauthorized access to the administrator account due to a lack of configuration of the account and its security mechanisms, making it possible to modify credentials and add/remove user accounts.

threat.name: Attackers gain unauthorized access to the user account due to the lack of configuration of the account
threat.desc: Attackers could gain unauthorized access to the user account due to the lack of configuration of the account, for example, the security question to reset the password is configured incorrectly.

threat.name: Attackers gain unauthorized access to the control of the environment
threat.desc: Attackers could potentially gain unauthorized access to the control of the environment, due to user accounts - or role groups - not being well defined and configured. As a consequence attackers may be able to make changes without root approval.

threat.name: Attackers gain access to the system by exploiting weak security configurations
threat.desc: Weak security configurations like using sharing passwords in plain text, using weak passwords, using obsolete encryption algorithms, etc. can lead attackers to gain access to the system.

threat.name: Attackers access the systems without being detected
threat.desc: Attackers gain access to the systems and are not detected and consequently, changes made by attackers can not be audited or detected.

threat.name: Attackers gain undetected access to the security system configurations
threat.desc: Attackers could gain undetected access to the security system configurations and changes made by attackers couldn't be audited or detected.

threat.name: Sensitive data is compromised through network access
threat.desc: Attackers gain undetected access to the network systems and changes made by the attackers couldn't be audited or detected.

threat.name: Attackers gain unauthorized connection to the resources
threat.desc: Attackers could potentially gain unauthorized connection to the resources through misconfigured ports or security network configurations.
